text: What's up, outliers? Quick market update. Two things on the agenda. First we have Visa with its new antitrust lawsuit coming out, which we'll talk about quickly. And then we're going to take a look at you, meaning Unity, because there's a lot of talk about some trades flowing in that are of interesting size, meaning 5,000 lot options trades. That's actually popped up earlier for me today. And I think it's kind of interesting to keep an eyeball on. So let's start with Visa. What's going on here? Well, it's pretty straightforward. So you can see that the Justice Department accuses Visa of stifling competition in the debit hard business. So why does this matter? Well, it essentially shows that the Justice Department is starting to attack some of these perceived monopolies. I don't exactly want to go as far as to call it as a monopoly, but you can see that Visa controls more than 60 of debit card processing. And this is one of the really interesting factors that go into a economy and overall capitalistic structure like we have here is where is that line drawn between letting good businesses grow and thrive versus good businesses being given excess advantages that then allow them to dominate a landscape. And it's a really interesting discussion to be had. But we can see here, it says Visa handles more than 60 of debit card transactions and collects more than 7 billion in annual processing fees. And it uses

So that's actually meaning that there is a pretty significant amount of debit card transactions that happen. And I just find that generally interesting because that really bolsters this argument that there's a pretty significant market here that Visa is looking to dominate. So we can see that merchants are on board because obviously they just pass through the cost anyway. They generally don't care. And it says Tuesday's lawsuit is not the first time Visa's run a foul of the Justice Department four years ago, the government suits a block visa from acquiring a Fintech company, Plaid, which most of us are familiar with. And it says if you the 5.3 billion takeover as an insurance policy to prevent Plaid from infringing on its lucrative debt debit card. And again, that's the, this is something that we saw through Facebook previously now meta that they used to literally buy companies and just nuke the company to get rid of the competition. And again, it's really hard to say in a theoretical standpoint, if that's good, if that's bad, if that is capitalistic, if it's not, if there should be regulation. And these are the arguments that are going to be had by people of different opinions. But what I can tell you is that there is a tradable event here.
